ground_truth_articulation: Text is classified as TRUE if the variance of word lengths (split by spaces) is less than 2.0, indicating consistent word length distribution.
generated_articulation: The output is True when the input contains at least one common word that appears at least twice, regardless of order, indicating the presence of repeated words; it is False when all words are unique or no word repeats.
raw_response: The output is True when the input contains at least one common word that appears at least twice, regardless of order, indicating the presence of repeated words; it is False when all words are unique or no word repeats.
llm_judge_reasoning: The ground truth rule classifies texts based on the consistency of word lengths, specifically whether their variance is below 2.0, which measures how uniform the word lengths are. The generated rule classifies texts based on the presence of repeated words, regardless of length or distribution. These are fundamentally different features: one focuses on the distribution of word lengths, the other on word repetition. They are unlikely to produce the same classifications on most inputs, as a text could have uniform word lengths without repeated words, or contain repeated words with highly variable word lengths. The core concepts—word length variance versus repeated words—are not equivalent, making the rules largely unrelated in their logic.
